content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

```julia
function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df.ym = map(x -> string(floor(Int, x.year)) * 100 + string(x.month), df.dt)
    return df
end
```

This function assumes that the `DateTime` column `dt` in the DataFrame has a field called `year` and another called `month`. It then uses `floor` to round down the year to the nearest whole number (since `Int` does not have a fraction part), and concatenates the year with 100 times the month as an integer to ensure that the resulting string is in the format "yyyymm". Finally, it maps this transformation over each element in the column and assigns it to a new column `ym` in the DataFrame.
